habitat_description:
During the breeding season, N. americanus inhabits short to mixed-grass prairie, meadows, herbaceous wetlands, playas, shrub steppe, pasture/hayfields, and cultivated cropland (Cochrane and Anderson, 1987; Saunders, 2001; Dechant et al., 2002; Dugger and Dugger, 2002; Saalfeld et al., 2010). It prefers vegetation < 20 cm in height (Neel, 1999). Long-billed curlew ranges from near sea level up to 2200 m (Southwest Regional Gap Analysis).

The species’ winter range is predominantly coastal, and winter habitat includes: low elevation meadows, pasture/hayfields, cultivated cropland, tidal estuaries, mudflats, salt marshes, grasslands, and herbaceous wetlands (Stenzel, 1976; Gerstenberg, 1979; Brush, 1995; Shuford et al., 1998; Dugger and Dugger, 2002).

N. americanus nests and forages within 1000 m of water (per expert review).
